name: sfchronicle
text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
What can $1,000 a month do for you? And you? And you?

@JFagone talks to @DemianBulwa about what Universal Basic Income can mean for individuals, and for places like Marin City, which has been left behind by the boom.

Listen üéß:
https://t.co/JhU4AhqHfr

name: sfchronicle
text: Take Marin City and Sausalito as an example: How would these cities change if every adult got $1,000 a month, no questions asked? Reporter @JFagone takes a look at how UBI could be an equalizing force: https://t.co/4nimRuyA6J

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/XbHs1UO6jq

name: sfchronicle
text: Hundreds of workers at Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital, including nurses, started a strike Monday morning that is expected to last five days. The hospital employees have worked without a contract for more than a year, according to union officials. https://t.co/nSsrE0RLNe https://t.co/pTIh6M5idF

name: sfchronicle
text: An experimental coronavirus vaccine in an early British trial prompted a protective immune response in hundreds of people who received it, the Associated Press reports. https://t.co/7QnEDV4nDt https://t.co/ONwYgXIBMF

name: sfchronicle
text: Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, San Francisco, San Mateo and Santa Clara counties all fall short of their goal of doing case investigations for 90% of the people who test positive for the coronavirus. https://t.co/tqSVGm19bs

name: sfchronicle
text: For the first time, the Bay Area‚Äôs largest planning agencies have mapped what the region might look like in 2050 ‚Äî and it‚Äôs a place where new jobs and housing increasingly migrate to the South Bay. https://t.co/SqDxzbbzbT

name: sfchronicle
text:
Community Foods Market in West Oakland temporarily closes after employee tests positive for coronavirus. Fearing other workers were exposed to the virus, the grocery store was shuttered Monday for a deep cleaning and review of safety protocols. 
https://t.co/qfHq1RGiY5

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúWe are experiencing some issues in terms of obtaining (protective equipment), likely due to the increased national demand for supplies,‚Äù Dr. Grant Colfax, director of the S.F. Public Health Department, said in a news briefing Wednesday. https://t.co/v85HwAD5Ql

text:
San Mateo County, which resumed jury trials five weeks ago, suspended them for 30 days Monday after an employee tested positive for coronavirus during jury selection.
https://t.co/cKYOtZj7gY

name: sfchronicle
text:
Californians will be allowed to get their hair cut and nails done outdoors, Gov. Newsom said Monday, a week after he ordered personal care services shuttered in most of the state amid a surge in coronavirus cases.
https://t.co/AQm3N2K5AU

name: sfchronicle
text:

https://t.co/HwuhoOA8ch

name: sfchronicle
text:
About 1,500 janitors in San Francisco walked off the job and hundreds of protesters gathered outside City Hall on Monday, as part of a national movement. The Strike for Black Lives protests extended to more than two dozen U.S. cities. 

https://t.co/qK5PH4pT0j

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: California progressives are not letting up on Joe Biden after he released a clean-energy plan last week that is more left-leaning than what he campaigned on during the primaries. https://t.co/vcGfXa57l5

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúOur health has never been at greater risk. We need our hospital to support us, not squeeze us for every last dime during a pandemic.‚Äù Hundreds of health care workers began a planned five-day strike Monday at Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital. https://t.co/cysy7zHBc0

name: sfchronicle
text:
Caltrain is struggling as ridership plunges during the pandemic. A contentious sales tax, initially proposed to fund service expansion, may now be needed to keep the rail line operational, some say.

https://t.co/DX0oZfs9bc

text:
